editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Thompson Family Charitable Trust

supportDesc.support: Comprising three originally separate MSS, all on vellum (the second HSOS/HFFH, the others FSOS/FHHF).
supportDesc.extent: Fols. iii + 376 (numbered fols. 1–375, iv) + ii (numbered fols. v–vi). 162 117
supportDesc.condition: Borders cut away on fols. 77 and 97.

binding.p: A modern replacement. Sewn on five thongs. At the front, a marbled paper leaf, one modern paper flyleaf, and one medieval vellum fiyleaf at the rear, a modern paper flyleaf, and another marbled leaf (v–vi).

history.provenance: Part of a verse (fol. ivv, s. xvi).
history.acquisition: ‘Liber Collegij Divi Johannis Baptistae Oxon’ ex dono Domini Gulielmi Paddei Militis et ejusdem Collegii olim Convictoris 1634’ (fol. 2, upper margin).

source.bibl: Ralph Hanna, A descriptive catalogue of the western medieval manuscripts of St. John's College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact St John's College Library.

listBibl.bibl: Alexander, J. J. G., and Elźbieta Temple, Illuminated Manuscripts in Oxford College Libraries, the University Archives and the Taylor Institution (Oxford, 1985).
Catalogue of Books Printed in the XVth Century Now in the British Museum, 8 vols. (London, 1909).
Demaître, Luke, ‘The Relevance of Futility: Jordanus de Turre (fl. 1313–1335) on the Treatment of Leprosy’, Bulletin of the History of Medicine 70 (1996), 25–61.
Hain, L., Repertorium bibliographicum, 8 vols. (Stuttgart, 1826–38, repr. Milan, 1948), with Supplement by W. A. Copinger (London, 1895–1902; repr. Milan, 1950).
Kibre, Pearl, Hippocrates Latinus: Repertorium of Hippocratic Writings in the Latin Middle Ages, rev edn. (New York: Fordham University Press, 1985).
Thorndike, Lynn, and Pearl Kibre, A Catalogue of Incipits of Medieval Scientific Writings in Latin, 2nd edn. (Cambridge, Mass., 1963).
Walther, Hans, Initia carminum ac versuum Medii Aevi posterioris Latinorum, 2nd edn (Göttingen, 1969).

msItem.incipit: Quoniam secundum doctrinam G 3o de ingenio sicut sciencia operandi ab essencia morbi finitur ita
msItem.explicit: coxi uirere aloen ana vncia 1. etsi buthiri quod sufficit ficit emplastrum Deo gracias
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit paruus tractatus GUIDONIS super antidotario
msItem.title: 'Paruus tractatus super antidotario'
msItem.note: Perhaps GUY OF CHAULIAC (so TK 1301), another copy Poitiers, BM, MS 185, fol. 13. Fol. 32rv is blank but ruled.

msItem.incipit: Intendens venerabilis amice bernarde componere librum in quo tradam omnium concedente datore plenam doctrinam [fol. 33v, the text] Attende quod in omni opere medicus debet supponere circam intencionem
msItem.explicit: tibi graciam specialem qui tibi donet graciam suam mihi aut veniam peccatorum qui sit benedictus in secula seculorum amen
msItem.author: LANFRANC OF MILAN
msItem.title: Cyrurgia parva
msItem.note: (TK 757), ed. Cyrurgia Guidonis de Cauliaco (Venice, 23 December 1499) (Hain 4812*, BMC5:575) 171ra–75vb.

collation.catchwords: Catchwords in scrolls, most cut away.
collation.signatures: Only one early signature (fol. 19 = c iij), but in booklet 2 all leaves in the first half of each quire signed with a letter and a roman numeral, many cut away; in this system, quires 5, 8–9 = a, d–e.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 25 lines to the page. No prickings; bounded and ruled in purple and pinkish inks.

handDesc.handNote: Written in French lettre bâtarde, i.e., bastard secretary s. xv2. Punctuation by point and virgula.

decoDesc.decoNote: At heads of the two texts of the MS, a 5-line champe with simple bar extensions and full floral demivinet on the other three sides of the page, in green, gold, blue, and pink (the first champe green, blue, and gold leaf).
At chapter heads, alternate 2-line lombards, blue on red flourishing and gold leaf on purple flourishing.
The text divided by alternate red and blue paraphs and ochre-slashed capitals (occasional ochre-slashed top line extenders, some elaborated into snake shapes).
In the margin fol. 23v, drawings of surgical implements.
See AT, no. 762 (75), dating 1450 at Avignon on the basis of fol. 125v; with ‘fine borders in the same style added, fols. 291–372, to an Italian MS of s. xiii2/4’, and plate xlv (fol. 105).

msItem.incipit: Ut de operatione manuali librum componerem breuiorem scilicet et apciore quam composuerim Andree tuam mihi peticionem paduanensis lazare
msItem.rubric: [fol. 77v, the text] De sermone naturali in vulneribus
msItem.incipit: Primus canon seu Regula que in omnibus occurrit vulneribus est Ut sanguis refrenetur
msItem.explicit: ad remedium tocius corporis Et cum fit etiam in concauitate pedis valet ad podagram
msItem.author: BRUNO LONGOBURGENSIS
msItem.title: Cyrurgia minor
msItem.note: (TK 1122; 1615 for the prologue), ed. Cyrurgia Guidonis, 94ra–96vb.

msItem.incipit: Liberet te deus fili amantissime a deuio erroris et in via conseruet prosperitatis
msItem.explicit: non per omnia habeo ceptum opus non negligere hortor per quod idem nunis letificasti
msItem.author: JOHN DAMASCENUS
msItem.title: Anforisimi
msItem.note: TK 824, ed. Aphorismi excellentissimi Raby Moyses [Maimonides] (Bologna, 28 May 1489) pt. 2 (Hain 10524*, BMC 6:824), sigs. A i–A v.

msItem.rubric: Incipiunt Amphorisimi seu parabule magistri ARNAUDI DE VILLANOUA
msItem.incipit: Omnis medela procedit a summo bono Qui Iuste ac vtiliter voluerit medicari
msItem.explicit: Sapiencie igitur ad exemplum illius premiss reducit in parabolas oportunas
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt amphorismi seu parabole magistri ARNALDI DE NOUA VILLA per me Io duraund compagnoni tunc in Ciuitate Auinion’ et in camera venerabilis viri domini Jacobi oboli canonici sancti petrj degen MoCCCClmo. deo gracias
msItem.author: ARNOLD OF VILLANOVA
msItem.title: 'Amphorisimi seu parabule'

msItem.rubric: Isti versus statim sequentes ostendunt et demonstrant cognoscere quatuor complexiones
msItem.incipit: Fleuma superueniens propria in corpore leges | Artus suspend’ lacerni
msItem.explicit: aut elephancia pestis | Hinc pars maiores hinc mortificacio partis
msItem.note: TK 565, 566 and Walter, no. 6606 (cf. BL, MSS Royal 12 D.xiii, fol. 209; or Sloane 783B, fol. 179), in part excerpted from the ‘Schola Salerni’. Fols. 127v–8v are blank but ruled.

msItem.rubric: Incipit codicillus Magistri BERNARDI DE GORDONIO
msItem.incipit: Circa omnium egritudinum genera Triplex modus curatonis curationis occurrit Primus est per exhibitionem
msItem.explicit: desiccabitur Informentur Inde trocissi et bene desiccati vsui reseruentur finis
msItem.author: BERNARD DE GORDON
msItem.title: Codicillus
msItem.note: TK 217 (perhaps another text with the same incipit). There is a thoroughly obliterated inscription at the foot of fol. 255v, and fol. 256 is blank but ruled.

msItem.incipit: Dicitur vrina quoniam fit renibus vna | Aut ab vrit grece
msItem.explicit: ne casta reuelet | Fibria monstratur quam non est tangere dignus
msItem.author: GILES OF CORBEIL
msItem.title: De urinis
msItem.note: (TK 422), ed. Louis Choulant, Carmina Medica (Leipzig, 1826), 4–18. Written by a new scribe; introduced by only a 4-line champe and with a plainer border; alternate 1-line lombards and red paraphs.

msItem.incipit: Ingenii vires modicis conatibus impar | Materies onerosa
msItem.explicit: exponens diuite vena | Iam sterilem cultum philareti nominis horret
msItem.author: GILES
msItem.title: De Pulsibus

msItem.rubric: Sequntur versus eiusdem super antidotarium de syrupo rosarum
msItem.incipit: Syrupus ex rosis In febre valet peracuta | Quartana terreo stomaco
msItem.explicit: veramque diurnam | Fastidium tollit stomachi chimis ab acutis
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt versus de vtilitatibus medicinarum compositarum secundum antidotarium ARNOLDI DE VILLANOUA.
msItem.author: ARNOLD OF VILLANOVA
msItem.title: 'Antidotiarum'
msItem.note: Cited TK 1510 and not in Walther (nor ed. by Choulant).

msItem.incipit: Cognoscuntur leprosi quinque modis scilicet ab vrina a pulsu a sanguine a voce
msItem.explicit: [fol. 287] Si autem appareant signa melancolie erit species que vocatur elephantia
msItem.incipit: Quoniam autem omnis operatio medicaminum secundum rectam viam que sumitur
msItem.explicit: nisi mundificatiua cutis et per medicinas fortes quas ponunt doctores Deo gracias
msItem.author: JORDANUS DE TURRE
msItem.title: tract on leprosy
msItem.note: the first part ed. as ARNOLD OF VILLANOVA, ‘Signa leprosorum’ (TK 232), Opera, 1520–4; the second part (not in TK) ed. Luke Demaître, ‘The Relevance of Futility: Jordanus de Turre (fl. 1313–1335) on the Treatment of Leprosy’, Bulletin of the History of Medicine 70 (1996), 25–61 at 54–61. At the end, most of fol. 291v and all fol. 292v blank but ruled. At the head, a space for a 3-line initial unfilled; perhaps an unexccuted planned border (the top lines blank). Rules in pinkish ink.

collation.formula: 1112 128 [fol. 96, a booklet boundary] | 138 [fol. 104, a booklet boundary] | 14–168 [fol. 128, a booklet boundary] | 17–2712 2810 2914 [to fol. 284, a booklet boundary] | 308.
collation.catchwords: Within continuous sections, catchwords near the gutter, usually in red half-boxes.
collation.signatures: Signatures only in the fourth booklet (arabic numerals on the first three leaves of the fifth): all leaves in the first half of each quire signed with a letter and a roman numeral (arabic on a few occasions); in this system, quires 17–27 = a–?k. These signatures have been imposed on an earlier system which signed sheets, rather than bifolia, and which did not assign numerals (which usually appear to have been added) to the leaves.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 29 lines to the page. Prickings; bounded and ruled in purple ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in French cursiva (secretary), s. xv3/4 (a new scribe probably takes over at fol. 105). Punctuation by point and double virgula.

decoDesc.decoNote: Seven-line champes at initia, with full borders (some cut away). That at fol. 105 in light green and pink with minimal gold-work; that at fol. 129 12-line, with the opening word as part of the painting, and with a blazon worked into the gold, now illegible.
At chapter heads, 3- and 4-line alternate lombards, blue on red flourishing and gold leaf on purple flourishing.
The texts divided by alternate red and blue paraphs and, in booklet 4, some ochre-slashed capitals.

msItem.incipit: Medicina diuidit diuiditur [sic] in duas partes scilicet in theoricam et practicam Quarum theorica diuiditur
msItem.explicit: cognicio quinque modis sit qualitatis quantitatis temporis ordinis boni mauve discretione
msItem.author: HUNAIN IBN ISHAQ
msItem.title: Isagoge in Tegni Galieni
msItem.note: (TK 856), ed. Articella, 1:2ra–4va. The repetition in the incipit, hereafter ignored, results from the lack of coordination between the scribe and the rubricator producing a painted display opening.

msItem.incipit: Tres sunt omnes doctrine que ordine habentur prima quidem ex finis notione
msItem.explicit: et perscribens quot sint et qualia determinabo orationern in eis
msItem.author: GALEN
msItem.title: Ars parva/Microtechne
msItem.note: (TK 1585), ending in 3.214, ed. Articella, 3:84va–153rb. Fol. 332v is blank but ruled; the foot of both the recto and the verso have added medical notes and distinctions.

msItem.incipit: Uita breuis ars uero longa tempus acututum experimentum fallax iudicium difficile
msItem.explicit: non existente in collo suffocatio repente inuascatur et deglutire non posset mortale
msItem.author: HIPPOCRATES
msItem.title: Aphorismi
msItem.note: in the translation of CONSTANTINE THE AFRICAN, ending 7.59, ed. Articella, 2:1ra–139ra. Our MS is unnoted in Kibre’s Hippocrates Latinus. Each section introduced by a 1-line red or blue lombard. Fol. 346v is blank.

msItem.incipit: Omnis qui medicine studio seu gloriam seu delectabilem amicorum consequi desiderat copiam
msItem.explicit: nostro numero dierum nostrorum quoquo sunt exposite ordine preceptorum
msItem.author: HIPPOCRATES
msItem.title: Prognostics
msItem.note: also translated by CONSTANTINE, ed. Articella, 2:141ra–67va.

msItem.incipit: De urinarum differencia negocium multi ueterum medicorum agressi sunt scribere
msItem.explicit: quidem disciplina et secundum genera et species et differencias conuenienter exposuimus
msItem.author: THEOPHILUS
msItem.title: De urinis

msItem.incipit: [unfilled blank for decorated text opening] habemus in presenti conscriptione de pulsuum negocio compendiosam expositionem tradere
msItem.explicit: in una diastole differenter facere motiones vt [later CW: capra saliens]
msItem.author: PHILARETUS
msItem.title: De pulsibus
msItem.note: (TK 764), ed. Articella, 1:4ra–5rb (nearly complete). The text breaks off at the foot of a page, and fol. 368 is blank and appears to be a modern supply.

msItem.incipit: [unfilled blank for decorated text opening] accidentibus in singulis egritudinibus tractantes poenis consensisse feruntur eos quidem in hiis
msItem.explicit: hiis minus congruus est qui solo dictantur potu sed illis aliquando conueniens est
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber YPOCRATIS perion oxion noxomaton
msItem.author: HIPPOCRATES
msItem.note: The Regimen in acutis morbis, translated by CONSTANTINE, ending in a gloss-like explanation of 2.52, ed. Articella, 3:1ra–19rb. Fol. 375v was originally blank, now filled with medical materials; the leaf appears to have been originally waste, cut from a larger leaf in multiple columns with an index of herb simples.

supportDesc.foliation: An accurate medieval foliation, numbering fols. 293–374 to fol. lxxxij (most cut away).
supportDesc.collation: 31–344 358 36–394 [fol. 332, a booklet boundary] | 40–484 [fol. 368, a booklet boundary] | 494 502 (? now both single) 512 (followed by a stub). One catchword (fol. 364v), no signatures.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 30 lines to the page. No prickings; bounded and ruled in lead and black ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in Italian (?) gothic textura quadrata, s. xiii in. (above top line), one scribe for fols. 293–343, 347–64v; a second for fols. 343v–6; a third for fols. 365–75. Punctuation by point, medial point, and punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: At the head of the first text, an 8-line champe, with the opening line painted in alternating red and blue lombards. (The rubricator filled the whole line, even if this involved duplication of the text already copied.)
Provided with a floral border, s. xv.
The last few texts have spaces for this treatment but are not filled.
At chapter heads, 2-line alternate red and blue lombards with minimal touches in the other colour; the text broken with 1-line unflourished examples.

revisionDesc.change: Sebastian Dows-Miller. Corrected typo in handNote script.
